{"blocks":[{"key":"1kjr5","text":"This protocol is the complete methods used to extract abundance, morphology and color data from samples of invertebrates.  We developed this protocol specifically to measure invertebrate by-catch from pitfall traps collected by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), but these methods could be extended to any invertebrate samples.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5v3o","text":"

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"54lok","text":"We use a Canon EOS 5Ds (Model DS526521) camera fitted with a Canon EF 35mm f/2 IS USM  Lens (Model 9523B002).  To avoid having to recharge the battery we use a fixed power supply (Glorich Model #WP-AC08030V).  The camera is mounted on a Diagnostic Instruments Heavy Duty Boom stand.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7o436","text":"Attach AC power supply to camera (or you will need to disconnect from boom to recharge/replace batteries).  Attach camera to boom stand pointing down towards table top. Our set up is has a distance of 29.5 cm from the lens to the tile surface.  To measure this, stack two tiles on the table top.  Use a small bubble T-level to make certain the table and the camera are in the same plane. Load Canon EOS Utility onto laptop.  Connect camera to the laptop with a USB-A to Micro-B USB 3.0 cable. Plug in camera power supply.  If logged in, turning on the camera should open the Canon EOS Utility","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f752q","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e3j9t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"071740E026C511EC99C967924E6CA43E","height":436.5,"id":138254,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8i826","text":"Camera attached to boom stand with power supply and USB cable attached.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Camera Set up.jpeg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehasbjtzp.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehaqbjtzp.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/eharbjtzp.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehapbjtzp.webp","width":291.0000000000001}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2r7ne","text":"Construct 4 lighting rigs. Put together the 4 Savage Studio Light Kits  (Savage LED30 bulbs are 5500K, 35W). The top of the stand, before adding the lamp is 27.5 inches above table level.  Add the lamp to the top of the stand at a 45° angle.  At the base of each light stand, use two zip ties to attach a power supply.   Attach two clamp lights (one to each side left and right) with the center of the lightbulb at 18 inches above table level, and two more with the center of the light bulb at 4 inches.  Center each lighting rig on each 25 inch side of the diffuser box.  Place each as close to the diffuser as possible without touching, but be equidistant on each side. When placing each lighting rig in place, adjust all lights to point directly at the center of the tile stage.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2qddi","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6hkc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"935C1BB026C611EC99C967924E6CA43E","height":460,"id":138258,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"76fgs","text":"One of the four lighting rigs. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"_lighting rig.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehawbjtzp.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehaubjtzp.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehavbjtzp.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehatbjtzp.webp","width":301}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cnn3u","text":"Construct diffuser box.   Make two squares using the 25-inch pvc pipes with the four open slips pointing in the same direction.  Connect the two squares using the 4  36-inch pcv pipes, thus making a 25\" by 25\" by 36\" (tall) cuboid.  For each face of the cuboid, attach the diffuser cloth using two spring clamps on the horizontal top bar and one on each of the vertical bars. Adjacent sides on the vertical use a single clamp for both diffuser cloths.  Place diffuser box so that the boom enters the diffuser box touching one of the vertical pipes. {"blocks":[{"key":"f9990","text":"We are imaging alcohol stored 14-day pitfall samples from NEON.  Our goal is to get the samples imaged before they dry out, so we often have to take multiple images to complete a sampling event as these samples can have \u003e2000 individuals per sampling event.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4m866","text":"Mark off 12- by 12-inch ceramic tile so that all individuals, labels and color selector card/reference ruler will be in a rectangle 8 inches wide by 12 inches tile.  These dimensions take advantage of the native 3:2 camera settings and allow higher resolution than imaging a square foot tile. Place the color selector card in the bottom right and all labels from the tube in the bottom left of the rectangle. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1kqo","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3io80","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"F3EBBBF026C811EC99C967924E6CA43E","height":404.50909090909084,"id":138274,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fosd8","text":"Sample image, downscaled from 110mb original. {"blocks":[{"key":"8vkuc","text":"Directory Structure: Some of the FIJI scripts below will open and save files to and from other directories.  To avoid path problems, use this structure for the project directory.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2e1qu","text":"\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mu07","text":"PROJECT","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfar9","text":"    /IMAGES/                    (1-8 below are divided into site specific directories.)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqmjf","text":"        /1_RAW/                 Houses the .CR2 raw files","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2aovn","text":"        /2_CROPPED/       Houses the cropped .TIF files","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"175o7","text":"        /3_BINARY/           Houses the red binary .TIF files ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8kehj","text":"        /4_ROI/                  Houses the Regions Of Interest .ROI file from FIJI ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3cb4j","text":"        /5_RESULTS/        Houses the .CSV measurements file generated from FIJI ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"g50n","text":"        /6_CHOP/             Houses the individual .TIF images. Each image needs a directory within this","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f60ih","text":"        /7_TAXA/              Houses the .CSV measurement files copied from /5_RESULTS/ to add taxon id's","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"gos3","text":"        /8_COLOR/            Houses the color data extracted by coi","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3u4il","text":"Turn on all lights and set Savage LED60K to maximum.  Turning on the camera should turn on Canon EOS Utility.  Select \"Remote Shooting\" which will open a new window.  Camera settings:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fr2fa","text":"    1. F-stop= F22","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"39clg","text":"    2. Shutter Speed= 1/30","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2t12d","text":"    3. ISO= 500","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"165ua","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9b1dd","text":"Choose \"Live View Shoot.\"  Under \"Focus\" choose FlexiZone= \"Single\" and set Continuous AF \"On.\"  Use the cursor to set the autofocus zone on the smallest organisms in the image. If you set in on a large individual, there will be a depth of field problem for the small individuals.  Select the correct folder to house the image. Take image.  Save image to /PROJECT/IMAGES/1_RAW/SITE/","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45dsi","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cnb4i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"26E2F4A026CA11EC99C967924E6CA43E","height":259.6909090909091,"id":138278,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1apat","text":"Sample screen-cap of .CR2 raw image. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Screen Shot 2021-10-06 at 12.23.12 PM.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehbibjtzp.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehbgbjtzp.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehbhbjtzp.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ehbfbjtzp.webp","width":392.39010989010984}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"amgoq","text":"This section converts the raw .CR2 file into morphometric and color data as well as creating a new, smaller image for each individual. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fe7fo","text":"Crop raw .CR2 photo and convert to a .tif file. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":48}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a1v27","text":"Open photo in Photoshop.  If necessary, rotate from horizontal to vertical, crop so that only the tile is shown in the image.  Make certain that all individuals, labels and the color selector card are visible in the image. Note that cropping the image does not change the resolution.  Save this file as a .tif file  using the following settings: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ab9r","text":"        1. Image Compression=\"None\"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7v8dp","text":"        2. Pixel Order=\"Interleaved\"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5v1ha","text":"        3. Byte Order=\"Macintosh\" (unless you are not using a mac)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"372fq","text":"        4. Layer Compression: (None of the three choices should be selectable)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b2ois","text":"Convert cropped .tif file to \"red\" binary file.  The goal of the two step color thresholding is to create a file that accurately and completely differentiates between the organism and the tile background (and is thus \"binary\").","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rvc1","text":"        1. Open cropped .tif file in FIJi","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2grdi","text":"        2. Select  Image -\u003e Adjust -\u003e Color Threshold","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fjfjb","text":"                 a. Thresholding method=MaxEntropy","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9rqg6","text":"                 b. Threshold color=Red","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fkuj9","text":"                 c. Color Space=RGB                    ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"49h84","text":"         Start with the following settings:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5j8vh","text":"                 d. Red= (0 , 255)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d196l","text":"                 e. Green= (0 , 170)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4631f","text":"                 f. Blue= (0 , 120)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ss35","text":"        If there are a lot of light colored organisms or parts not turning red, up the second blue value incrementally 10 units at a time.  Approaching (0 , 180), shadows will start to create \"fuzz\" around the edges of large-bodied organisms.      I reduce the blue value until these edges lose their \"fuzz.\"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9a83t","text":"          3.
